contentrichtext.text: '''Combat Zones That See''', or '''CTS''', is a project of the [[United States]] [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA) <ref name="darpa-solicitation">{{cite web|url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/DARPA_Solicitation_Number_SN03-13:_Pre-Solicitation_Notice:_COMBAT_ZONES_THAT_SEE_%28CTS%29|title=DARPA Solicitation Number SN03-13: Pre-Solicitation Notice: COMBAT ZONES THAT SEE (CTS)|publisher=Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> whose goal is to "track everything that moves" in a city by linking up a massive network of surveillance cameras to a centralised computer system.<ref name="vv">{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2003-07-08/news/big-brother-gets-a-brain/1|title=Big Brother Gets a Brain|last=Schachtman|first=Noah|date=July 8th 2003|work=Village Voice|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> [[Artificial intelligence]] software will then identify and track all movement throughout the city.<ref name="tether-statement">{{cite web|url=http://armed-services.senate.gov/statemnt/2005/March/Tether%2003-09-05.pdf|title=Statement by Dr. Tony Tether (DARPA) to the Senate Armed Services committee|last=Tether|first=Tony|date=March 9, 2005|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> CTS is described by DARPA as intended for use in combat zones, to deter enemy attacks on American troops and to identify and track enemy combatants who launch attacks against American soldiers.<ref name="vv" /> Civil liberties activists and [[George Orwell|writers of dystopian fiction]] believe that such programs have great potential for privacy violations, and have openly opposed the project.<ref name="vv" /><ref name="wired-another">{{cite news|url=http://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2003/07/59471|title=Another Tool For Big Brother?|date=July 2, 2003|work=Wired Magazine|accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref><ref name="glob-sec">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2003/030801-tech01.htm|title=Spy Project Driving Fear Of Surveillance|last=Sniffen|first=Michael|date=August 1,
